column11: What's your favorite thing about meeting with readers?
column12: What is the weirdest question you've ever gotten from a reader?
column13: What are you most looking forward to about the Collingswood Book Festival? (if you've been here before)

column3: Justin Coffin lives, works, and walks in Philadelphia. In addition to writing articles, essays, reviews, and plays over his 25-year career, heâ€™s ghostwritten a memoir, and published works on oddities of place and changing urban landscapes. His most recent work includes The Way Home, an essay that appears in Ways of Walking, an anthology edited by Ann de Forest; and El Bunny, a joint project with fine artist Terrence Laragione, the story of a Philadelphia neighborhood told by a person-sized rabbit.
column4: None. I'll be bringing some of my own.
column11: The surprises that come when discussing the work with people--to think more on what the work is about, to hear what readers think about when they read my work. Our relationship to our ideas and the things we make is always changing, and it's rewarding to catch up to what's new.

column3: Sannii Crespina-Flores has been a teaching artist, advocate, and activist for youth and women for more than twenty years, but it is the space between pen and paper that she finds sanctuary. A member of the Writers Guild of America (East) Indie Caucus and founder of the Un-Inhibited Muse Film Festival, the global youth initiative Do Remember Me, and the art collaborative Y
